Gentlemen:

I have to request that you will ship the following single school desks addressed to G. M. Campbell, Esq., Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ont:

9 Size #2 Globe No. 15 Sanitary Automatic Single Desks,
1 Rear.
1 Front.

These desks should be shipped knocked down and ink wells should be supplied with each. The price charged should be as low as possible, and should be F.O.B. Deseronto, Government sales tax included.

Please forward your account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the above desks to Mr. Campbell, who is being informed that the order has been placed with you, and requested, upon receipt of the desks, if in good condition, to certify the account and send it to the Department, when payment will be made.

I shall be pleased if you will arrange to make early shipment.

Yours very truly,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

The Globe Furniture Co., Ltd.,
Waterloo, Ont.
Ottawa, November 12, 1927.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, relative to the extra desks required for the use of the Eastern school on the Tyendinaga reserve.

We are today placing an order with the Globe Furniture Co. Ltd., Waterloo, Ont., to ship addressed to you the following desks:

9 Size No. 2 Globe No. 15 Sanitary Automatic Single Desks,
1 = = = = = = = = = = Rear,
1 = = = = = = = = = = Front.

These desks will be shipped knocked down and ink wells will be supplied with each. They will provide seating accommodation for 10 pupils. When they arrive, you should have them assembled and set up in the classroom in one row.

The account, which will cover the cost of the desks F.O.B. Deseronto, will be sent you in duplicate. Upon receipt of the desks, if in good condition, you should certify the account and send it to the Department in order that payment can be made.

It is hoped that, when these desks arrive, they will be satisfactory and will provide ample seating accommodation for all the children who attend this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

G. M. Campbell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.

There are no drinking cups supplied, but several families have their own cups at school. There are a few families however who have none.

The furnace is apparently all right, but the elbow in the smoke pipe is rusted out, so that there is a hole in it, and so far as I can find out, the pipes have not been cleaned for some considerable time.

Pipes for hot and cold air were reported in the Spring as being fouled by rubbish of various kinds. It is still there.

There is no clock in this school.

The waste pipe from the sink in the basement is still out of repair allowing the waste water to go on the floor. The pump for wash-water does not work properly.

Perhaps you do not wish me to report on these needed repairs. I would not infer from the fact that little or no attention is paid to the recommendations that I make. If that is your wish, will you kindly say so and, in future, I will make no comments whatever on this department of your schools.
Ottawa, October 25th, 1925.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Tyendinaga Eastern Indian Day School, states that there are no drinking cups supplied, but that some of the pupils take their own cups, while others have none. If you consider that a number of drinking cups are required, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a few enamelled cups.

The Inspector also states that an elbow in the smoke pipe of the furnace is rusted out and that the pipes have not been cleaned for some considerable time. Please arrange to have any elbows required installed and the pipes thoroughly cleaned.

The Inspector also states that the pipes for the hot and cold air are fouled by rubbish of various kinds. You should arrange to have these pipes cleaned out.

He also states that the waste pipe from the sink in the basement is still out of repair, allowing the waste water to go on the floor; also that the pump for wash water does not work properly. You should arrange to have this matter attended to.

The Inspector states that there is no clock in the school, you may purchase a clock of the Big Ben type, as it is considered this would be satisfactory for the purpose.

After you have completed the above repairs and purchased the clock, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

The Department will expect you to give attention to all of the above matters.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

G. M. Campbell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, November 10, 1925.

Sir:

It has been reported to the Department that one of the schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve which is near the highway requires painting. I presume it is the Eastern School as, after examining our files, I find that the other three schools on the Reserve were painted during the past summer. If this is so, I should be grateful if you would let me have your report and recommendation. It is too late to arrange for the painting this fall, but the matter must not be overlooked in the early spring.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Ottawa, April 19, 1929.

Sir:

Referring to conversation with you while in the Department today relative to the painting of the exterior of the Tyendinaga Eastern Day School building, you are authorized to make the necessary arrangements to have this work carried out during the coming summer holidays. This building should be given two coats of white paint, with green or brown trimmings. You should arrange for the purchase of a good grade of paint, oils, etc., and for the labour in having the work carried out. You should see that a satisfactory job is completed.

Labour returns, in duplicate, should be kept, a supply of which is enclosed for the purpose. Full particulars should be filled in on these forms as requested under the various headings, and they should be signed by the individual men employed and certified by you as Agent and then forwarded to the Department. You should also forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the paint, oils, etc., required.

You should keep all costs as low as possible, having in view the supplying of good materials and the carrying out of satisfactory work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

G. M. Campbell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR KEARNEY DATED JUNE 6TH, 1929, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE TYENDINAGA EASTERN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Original on File 34-2-6.

The school proper is modern in design and comparatively new. A coat of paint on the outside and better fences would improve appearances on this Provincial Highway, where tourists by the hundreds pass it in the course of the summer.

In October I reported to you that owing to a defective waste-pipe, water was leaking on to the floor from the sink in the basement. It is just the same today.
Ottawa, June 19th, 1929.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Tyendinaga Eastern School, draws attention to the need of painting the exterior of the school building and also to the providing of a fence. In this connection I have to refer you to official letters of April 19th and May 3rd, last, authorizing you to arrange for the painting of the exterior of the building and the outside closets and screens during the coming summer holidays. You were requested to furnish a report stating what new fencing you would recommend be carried out, giving an estimate of the materials required and the cost of same. The Department will be pleased to have this information at an early date, in order that any new fencing required may be carried out at the same time as the painting and other renovations to the school building are being undertaken.

The Inspector further states that, owing to a defective waste pipe, water leaks onto the floor from the sink in the basement and that these conditions have existed since October, last. The Department fails to understand why you should allow conditions of this nature to exist without taking the necessary action to have the repairs required carried out. You should see that this waste pipe is placed in good condition at an early date.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

G. M. Campbell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.
Sir,

In reply to your letter June 15th re Eastern School, I have asked for prices to paint this school and costs and expect to have them this week.

As to the fence, if we put a common woven wire it will take 11 rolls and 12 new posts which would cost about $11.00 for material and if we put in the steps as it is now they would cost for material $12.00.

And if you want a fancy fence it would cost around $3.00 per foot and the post would have to be next to the feet apart. I think the first fence would be the cheapest.

Your obedient servant,

G. M. Campbell

The Secretary
Dept. of Ind. Affairs
Ottawa
Ottawa, June 28th, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, relative to the painting of the exterior of the Eastern school on the Tyendinaga Reserve, also to the erection of a fence. It is noted that you will obtain prices for the painting, and it is hoped that you will be able to commence this work at an early date.

Relative to the fencing, as this school is situated on the main highway the fence fronting same should be of woven wire of an ornamental type, with sufficient new posts at proper intervals in order that it can be substantially erected. You should, therefore, obtain prices for the supplying of the fencing material and for the labour in erecting same, and this matter should receive your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.

I am pleased to note the preparation for a new fence in front of this property. Being situated directly on the Provincial Highway, this school is very conspicuous and should be kept up well. At present it looks tidy, except for the fence.

There is no drinking water here this morning. Is it not possible to provide your own water supply here? Children, as you are aware, require far more water than do adults and, when they have to carry it any considerable distance, they do not get nearly the amount they should have. It would not cost a great deal to drill a well here and, in my judgment, a drilled well is much to be preferred to a dug well at a school. You have a demonstration of this at the Mission where you dug a well some time ago and the children refuse to use the water.

This school is still without a clock, although I have repeatedly referred to the omission.

The only recommendation that I have to make at this time to improve your premises is that well and I sincerely hope that you will consider this favourably.
Ottawa, November 26, 1929.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Tyendinaga Eastern Indian Day School, recommends that a well be drilled in order to furnish an adequate supply of water for this school. He states that a drilled well is much preferable to a dug well and that the cost of obtaining a good supply of water at this school would not be large.

I shall be pleased to receive a report from you regarding the drilling of a well, stating whether you could arrange to have this work carried out at the present time, and, if so, the approximate cost per foot, and the depth you consider it would be necessary to drill in order to obtain a good supply of water. The cost of supplying the pump and necessary piping and the cribbing of the well should also be stated. You should give this matter your early attention and forward the information asked for, when consideration will then be given to having the well drilled.

Please also state whether the work in the erection of the new fence has been completed.

The Inspector states that this school is still without a clock and that one should be supplied. I have to request that you will arrange for the purchase and supplying of an inexpensive clock of the wall type. The clock, while serviceable, should be obtained as cheaply as possible, and an account, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded by you covering the cost. The purchase and delivery of this clock should receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Ottawa, June 9, 1931.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Tyendinaga Eastern Indian Day School, drew attention to the condition of the toilets. He states that the seat in the boys' toilet is filthy and the broken boards in the side of the building have not been repaired. He says, further, that glass for the windows in the boys' toilet has been in the school since last fall and asks why same was not put in place. He states also that there are some broken windows in the girls' entrance, which should be repaired.

I have to request that you will arrange to have the toilets repaired and placed in good condition during the summer holidays and any broken windows replaced. The Department will expect you to attend to these repairs in due time and that it will not be necessary to again draw the matter to your attention. Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my visit of inspection to the Tyendinaga Agency on the 30th and 31st ultimo.

SCHOOLS

There are four Indian Day schools in the agency with a total roll of 157. On the day of my visit there were 157 pupils present. The register shows a very satisfactory average attendance. The pupils are reported as making excellent progress. Discipline in the different schools is good and the deportment of the pupils shows the results of the interest taken in them by their teachers. Besides the regular curriculum they are taught the rudiments of agriculture, sewing, knitting and mending. The classrooms are well equipped and on the whole clean and well ventilated. The outside closets are not cleaned out often enough. They should be cleaned once a month during the summer months and treated with lime to prevent odor. This applies to all four schools.

Thos. Mc Cookin,

The Griffith Chemical Toilet has been designed to take care of problems of sewage disposal in districts that are not supplied with sewers or water supply.

No water is required. One illustration shows a vitreous china bowl with seat and cover set over a large cylindrical tank. The sewage drops directly into the tank where chemical sterilization and liquefaction takes place. All odours are carried off by the system of ventilation attached to the top of the bowl. This ventilation is extended upwards to a point above the roof peak.

Installation of the Griffith Toilet is a very simple matter as it is only necessary to place the bowl on the floor—place tank in position beneath the floor line—connect the bowl to tank—extend the ventilation pipe above the peak of the roof. All materials are supplied for a complete standard installation.

Griffith Toilets are absolutely odourless. Thousands of installations prove the merits of this equipment. Various sizes are built to take care of each problem. Full information mailed on request.
JUNIOR

Our "Junior" is constructed on the same sanitary principles as the "Griffith" but is a more moderately priced unit. SUCCESSORS TO

Sir,

I beg to ask if there are any funds available for the current year that could be applied toward the installation of a chemical toilet at the Eastern Day School, on the Tyendinaga Reserve.

I have to state that the present outside toilets connected with this school are unsanitary and not very satisfactory. This school which accommodates some forty seven pupils, is situated on the public highway which runs through part of the reserve, and the toilets in question are in a very exposed position both to the passing public, and also to the weather; during the winter time especially it is very hard to keep these toilets clean and sanitary owing to the fact that the snow and rain drives in causing the seats to become wet and frozen, the result is that the children who are confined at school all day without going home for midday meal, are constantly using the toilets, and in many instances have to stand upon the seats rather than use them in the ordinary manner, then again under the present conditions it is very difficult to keep these toilets cleaned properly.

This school is built in such a way that the installation of a chemical toilet would be an easy matter to install in the basement of the building, the approx cost of a toilet complete with two seats would be $250.00 or if a single seat is desired $125.00 this price includes all equipment making a complete odorless toilet, in the case of this school it would be necessary to have separate toilets for both boys and girls, but I think that one seat in each case might be sufficient for the present time.

I may say I have had an interview with a representative of the Eastern Sales Co., of Toronto Ont. who is handling this equipment, and from the description of the working of this toilet given by him I would suggest that it would be very suitable for this particular school.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Your Obedient Servant

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th ultimo, file 34-2-5, in which you advise me that provision has been made in the current year appropriation for an expenditure of $400.00 for repairs, improvements and equipment necessary at the four schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve.

In reply I have to state that the following repairs and equipment are necessary.

**Eastern School**
- Repairs to school entrances and porch floors
- Repairs to top and curbing of well
- Fence on West and North of school grounds needs repairing with new posts
- Outside lavatories in need of repair
- Material required for Fall Fair work

**Central School**
- New door required for main entrance, also door step renewed
- New screens required for windows
- New heater required for school, present heater in dangerous condition, fire pot badly cracked
- Four new desks required, attendance increasing and not sufficient seating room

**Western School**
- New pump head required, and pump overhauled
- Repairs to lavatories required
- Wooden ceiling of school room requires bracing
- Fence surrounding school grounds to be repaired and new posts put in where required

**Mission School**
- New main door required
- Screens required for windows, and door
- Blinds required for windows

In regard to the new heater required for the Central school, I beg to state that the present heater was purchased from the James
James Stewart Manufacturing Co., Woodstock, Ont. Name of heater, Good Cheer, No. 520. This heater has always given satisfaction and is a suitable type of heater for this school.

In regard to the new desks required, single seats are preferable, the present seats in the school are Style 3, supplied by A.S.M.C. School Furniture Co., Preston, Ont.

Your remarks in regard to the Eastern school have been noted and as much repair as possible will be placed on this school. I was hoping that this school at least could have received a coat of paint on the outside this year, but as this is impossible with the expenditure allowed for all four schools, I trust the Department will make a note of the fact that all schools are badly in need of outside painting, and that provision will be made in next years estimates if possible for the work to be done.

I should like to be advised as to when the work in the matter of repairs may proceed, and whether the Department will purchase the new equipment, or whether it will be in order to purchase through our local merchants.

The Secretary

Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ont.

Deseronto, Ont. February 17th 1942.

Dear Sir:

I would wish to advise you that the present desk accommodation at the Eastern Indian Day school is quite unsatisfactory and the immediate purchase of six large sized adjustable desks is recommended.

The enrollment at this school is 45 and since a number of pupils are now attending, that previously were students at the Deseronto Public School the number of large desks are insufficient to properly seat the pupils without discomfort, the present desks being low and without leg space, and are a menace to the health of the pupils.

The supplying of 5 new desks, Size 1; 1 Rear Size 1; 1 Front Size 1; would partially eliminate this cramped condition for the present and in the not-to-distant future it is my desire to make a survey of the desk accommodation at all the Agency schools and a recommendation to replace all the obsolete double desks now in use, with up to date single desks of proper sizes.

The Globe Furniture Co., Waterloo, Ont. have a Style 132 Steel Combination adjustable desk and the George M. Hendry Co., Toronto, Ont. have a "Preston" B.B.C. adjustable desk, either of these makes would be satisfactory and preferable for the Eastern School.

Extract from Indian Agent Moore's report on his inspection of the schools in the Tyendinaga Agency dated April 22, 1942.

At Eastern School there was considerable underbrushing to be done, old fence wire to be removed and a general cleanup made in the yard and this has been done. Spruce and cedar trees have been obtained from the Ontario Forestry Branch and have been planted around the yards at all four schools. All school grounds have been landscaped and a program of improving the appearance of these grounds commenced by the planting of shrubs and plants and it is hoped that this program can be continued in the coming years. The work of planting has been done by the pupils under the supervision of the teachers and I am trying to create a feeling of pride among the pupils in caring for school property which has been lacking considerable in the past. $5.00 a school was authorized for purchase of shrubs and plants and is not sufficient to make much impression and I would ask that this be increased to $15.00 a school, the extra $10.00 being needed for levelling of grounds, hauling earth for beds, and other necessities in preparing the grounds. An accountable cheque for $60.00 should come forward to pay for these needs.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed Credit Voucher No. 49 in favour of Tyendinaga Indian Agency Trust Account to the amount of $23.53 and being for shrubs purchased for the grounds of the Agency Indian Day Schools as was authorized by your letter 34-2-5 of April 29th. This purchase was made from funds advanced by departmental cheque #12891.

In an endeavor to improve the appearance of the school grounds a program of planting of spruce and cedar trees for a wind-break and elm and maple trees for shade trees has been inaugurated, flower beds made and shrubs planted by the pupils under the supervision of the school teachers. The trees were planted in good shape in sod and are now being kept clear of weeds and grass by the pupils so that they may obtain maximum growth.

Teams have been engaged to haul good earth for the planting of the shrubs and flowers and stone borders are being made around these beds and along with the fence posts of the school yards will be white-washed with lime, which I am procuring from the funds advanced.

While no great improvement can be expected this year it is hoped that the pupils will take an interest in the proper care of what has been supplied and that each Spring additional trees and shrubs will be planted, so that eventually a marked change will take place at these school grounds, which with the exception of Eastern School have been quite barren in the past.

Ottawa,

Mr. A.D. Moore, Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ont.

Inspector Arneil has recommended that additional land be obtained for the Tyendinaga Eastern School. I understand that he has discussed this matter with you and that the extra land needed can be obtained for an amount not exceeding $100.00. You should obtain an agreement from the person owning this land offering to sell it to the Department and at the same time you should describe the land in order that we may have the information required to obtain the necessary Order-in-Council.

Mr. Arneil also suggests the erection of a flag pole at this school. Arrangements can be made to have a flag pole cut in the bush and it should be placed at the Eastern School on a cement base. The expenditure should be kept as low as possible.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

I have your letter of May 18th concerning extra land for Tyendinaga Eastern School and would advise you that I approached Herbert Brant owner of the adjacent lot and learned from him that when the Ontario Highway Department constructed their No. 2 Highway they ran a large drain tile across this lot and material for levelling could not be obtained without interfering with the tile. Herbert Brant was also reluctant to sell as he had promised the lot to one of his son's to erect a home on the cement foundation in the lot.

Considering the cost of purchase at $100.00 and the cost of filling, levelling and seeding this ground with the cost of additional fences necessary, I am now of the opinion the better plan would be to install tile drain in the present school grounds and drain this land to an adjacent water course some total distance of 300 feet to which there is a very good fall. I enclose a rough sketch of how I would propose to install these tile and would not consider the cost of tile should exceed $50.00 with some cement at the outlet to eliminate damage by frost. The cost for labour should not exceed $75.00 at the most or a complete job for $125.00

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Deseronto, Ontario, June 30th, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Please find enclosed a requisition in duplicate for materials necessary to make repairs at the Eastern Indian Day School, Tyendinaga Reserve, which is estimated by me to cost in the vicinity of $350.00, which sum includes cost of labour.

Late last fall, sufficient field tile were purchased to drain the playground at this school and these tile should be installed this summer or fall, and I would estimate the cost of this work to be $100.00.

The classroom at this school has not been decorated for many years and the lighting is bad, and I would wish authority to paint the interior of the building. Two new entrance doors are needed, the present ones being the original doors and are very much repaired and dilapidated. A new floor is needed on the boys porch entrance on the west side of the school. Conductor pipes should be installed to the saps troughs on the west and north sides of the school to protect the foundation of the school proper. A complete new fence should be installed on the east side of the school lot.

As the children use the basement of the school for manual training and sewing work and this basement is also used by the Homemakers' Club, it is recommended that Donnacona board or Ten-test be installed on the ceiling rafters and stripped, thereby improving the appearance and heating of these rooms.

It is requested that authority be granted me to secure these supplies by local purchase which purchases can be
kept below $50.00 from separate merchants and by obtaining competitive prices. An advance cheque for labour of $200.00 should be sent forward when authority is granted for these repairs.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Mr. A.D. Moore, Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ontario,

You may purchase the materials required locally and it is noted that the total cost of the material will be approximately $150.65.

Under separate cover you will be forwarded an accountable cheque for $200.00 for labour.

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:-

With reference to the attached inquiry, we regret to disappoint, but have no stock at all of Wall Cupboards, nor are we able to indicate when it will be feasible to arrange to supply either #431 or #421. Both involve special manufacture, and there is a tremendous accumulation of business at the factory to clear before individual items, such as those mentioned, can be placed in work.

Dear Mr. Lewis,

Ottawa.

The undersigned trustees of the Mission School at Tyendinaga Reserve desire to ask the Department if the trustees of an Indian School such as ours, have any executive power. Our school yard requires fencing and we have approached the Chiefs in Council concerning it; but they with the Agent refuse to grant our request to provide for the fence. It is impossible to keep the yard clean as cattle are often allowed to be at large, especially those of the neighboring farmers.

Trusting,

James W. Barnhart

Trustees
EXD. Ottawa, March 2, 1911.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th ultimo, and in reply I beg to say that, as under the arrangement for the upkeep of the Indian schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve responsibility for buildings, etc., lies with the Indians, the white trustees cannot institute any proceedings which would result in an outlay of Indian funds.

As to the fencing of this ground I beg to say that this matter was brought to the attention of the Department by the Inspector last May and Mr. Stainton, the Indian Agent, was communicated with. I beg to quote from a letter received from him:— "It would to my mind be a waste of money to have this school fenced standing as it does in a beautiful hickory grove and in a secluded spot with very large grounds and on a side road not traveled as it would be were it situated on a main travelled road. It would scarcely appear that cattle would be troublesome as no cattle are allowed to run at large on any public road on this reserve. It would therefore appear to me as not being necessary to have a fence built and a waste of money therefore I would not recommend building a fence." In view of this information the Department did not consider it would be necessary to take any action to have the grounds fenced.

Your obedient servant,

James N. Bumbert, Esq.,
Deseronto, Ont.

Sir,

Your favour of the 2nd inst., received, and noticed that you apparently misunderstand one part of our letter. We are Indian Trustees of an Indian school in which there are no white trustees connected with it. We want to know if we, as Trustees of the Mission School, have any power in the management of the said school. We are elected regularly by the people of the school section, in the usual way.

The Chiefs claim that we have no power to engage teachers, or to discharge them, nor any of the powers usually vested to the trustees of the white schools.

Regarding the situation of the Mission School, we beg to inform you that it is not on a side road, but on the Slash Road, and that is a concession road. Moreover, the school lot lies at the jog in the Slash Road and cattle run across it when being driven to and from pasture. The untidy condition of the yard would convince anyone that a fence is badly needed there.

We beg to state further that there is no hickory grove near the school house. There is a small maple grove but that is on a neighbor's property.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE DEPUTY SUPERINTENDENT.

Messrs. J. N. Barnhart, D. H. Barnhart and J. A. Maracle, state that they are trustees of the Mission school on the Tyendinaga Indian Reserve, regularly elected by the people of the section in the usual way and they want to know if they have any power in the management of the said school, such as engaging teachers and discharging them and the powers usually vested in the trustees of the white schools.

These trustees I think have only such powers as may have been expressly given to them by the band or Council with the approval of the Superintendent General. Without such express authority I do not see how they could deal with school property or assume obligations with respect to school matters that would be binding on the band. They do not even represent the whole band, having been elected by one section of the band only. I am inclined to think that these trustees are in the position of a committee whose duty it is to make recommendations to the band with respect to school matters; but that the control of the school and the school property is in the hands of the band or Council, subject to the approval of the Superintendent General.

Law Clerk.

Ottawa, March 25, 1911.
Ottawa, March 27, 1911.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant in further reference to the powers of yourself and the other two trustees of the Mission school on the Tyendinaga Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that as trustees you have only such powers as may have been expressly given to you by the Band or Council with the approval of the Superintendent General. Without such express authority, therefore, you could not deal with school property or assume obligations on behalf of the band. It would appear, however, that your duties are confined to the making of recommendations to the Council in regard to school matters and that the claims of the Chief that you have no power to engage or discharge teachers or any of the powers usually vested in the trustees of white schools is well founded.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,

James N. Barnhart, Esq.,
Deseronto, Ont.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR H.J.CLARK ON THE TYENDINAGA(MISSION) SCHOOL.

The two smallest boys in this school had no dinner today.
I noticed they were not eating when the others were and made inquiry.
Inquiry, I do not know whether this occurs frequently or not.

they ate with a relish.

Ottawa, October 7th, 1915.

Sir,

In reporting on the Tyendinaga Mission school, Inspector Clarke stated that two of the smallest boys had no lunch and that he had to share his lunch with them. The Inspector did not give the names of the boys.

All the parents should take enough interest in the education of their children, to see that they are provided with lunch. Moreover, it is considered that all the parents are in a position to supply lunch for their children. You will be good enough to look into this matter and point out to the parents, in question, their duty in this matter.

Memorandum:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Mr. H. J. Eade, Indian Agent, Deseronto, Ont., has received the resignation of Thomas E. Emmons, teacher of the Mission Indian Day School on the Tyendinaga Reserve, No. 38 - Electoral District of Hastings South, Ont.

Mr. Eade requests that Miss Lilian Brant, an Indian girl, who is a member of the Tyendinaga Band and obtained her second class certificate two years ago, be appointed to succeed Mr. Emmons. Miss Brant has acted in the capacity of substitute teacher during the illness of the other teachers, in the schools on the reserve. I may say the Department assisted Miss Brant in attending high school and normal college. The salary rating at this school is $95.00 per teaching month, but it is considered that, as Miss Brant would start as a new teacher, the salary allowed her should be at the rate of $85 per teaching month. Mr. Emmons taught at this school for 8 years. The rating at the three other schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve is $90 per month, each.

I submit, for your approval, the appointment of Miss Brant, to begin duties on September third, next, the date the schools re-open after the present summer holidays.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum Mr. Scott,-

On July 16th last I made an inspection of the Mission School and grounds, Tyandinaga Indian Reserve, and beg to report that the school building is a balloon frame, 20 x 30 with a lean-to addition of 6 x 20 providing entrance and cloak-rooms.

The building is old, cold and poorly lighted, and is deteriorating rapidly, and while providing accommodation for the pupils enrolled, will soon require to be replaced by a new and modern type of school building.

The building is maintained in the best of condition possible under the circumstances. The plaster walls thoroughly painted as well as the wood work and show evidence of care and attention and a desire to maintain the building (including the floors) in a thorough sanitary condition. The painting, I am informed, was done entirely by the teacher and pupils, the money necessary having been provided through an entertainment held for this purpose. The efforts of the teacher in this direction is to be commended, as it is the only evidence found here during these inspections.
There are certain small repairs necessary in the interior, about three yards of plaster having fallen off and requires renewing, which should be repaired with wood fibre or other hard wall plaster at a probable cost of two or three dollars.

The closets are too small for the pupils these, and new ones should be provided at an early date.

School grounds are 120 x 240 ft. equal to about two-thirds of an acre. They provide adequate facilities for drainage and is a satisfactory school site.

The pupils enrolled here number 37 with an average attendance of 14, which is not a creditable showing. The attention of the Agent and truant officer should be drawn to this.

Architect.

Sir,

At a recent inspection of the school, it was noted that certain small repairs were necessary to the plaster, ceiling, etc., of the Mission school building, Tyendinaga Reserve. The repairs should be made at once with wood-fibred hard wall plaster, so that the can be tinted to correspond with existing walls.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Clarke, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mission School on the Tyendinaga Reserve, states that the new plaster has not been painted to correspond with the rest of the walls.

In your letter of the 25th of August, last, you stated that the teacher sold some of the old seats and was to have the new plaster painted and that you would see that this was done. You should have this work completed at once, and also state what authority the teacher had for selling the old seats.

The Inspector also states that there are no seats small enough for the smallest pupils and recommends that some of the seats in this school be moved to one of the other schools that require seats and that a row of smaller seats be taken from one of the schools that can supply them.

It is thought that arrangements could be made with some of the other schools to make a change in the seating at the Mission School. You will be good enough to look into this matter and try and arrange the necessary requirements as to the seating in these sub-clas.

The Inspector states that if the broken board in the rear of the boys' closet is not repaired the place will drift full of snow. You should attend to this matter at once and have all broken boards replaced.

Kindly give the matters mentioned above your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

G. M. Campbell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mission School on the Tyendinaga Reserve, states that the partially dug well is a menace and is dangerous in its unprotected state. In this connection I beg to say that, if this well is not required, it should either be filled in or a cover securely placed over the top to prevent any danger to the children. We understand that the water for school purposes is obtained from the well of Mr. R. Loft, which is situated about 200 yards from the school. It is hoped that the arrangement to provide the water needed from Loft's well can be continued. I shall be pleased to hear from you stating what you would recommend having done with this partially dug well.

The Inspector states that the toilets should be cleaned out. He says they are open on the back, making the pit an excellent breeding place for flies, and that they are very uncomfortable in winter. You should arrange to have these closets thoroughly cleaned out and put in good condition. The back should be closed in and made as comfortable as possible. Please have this work done at the lowest possible cost.

The Inspector further reports that the roof of the building leaks and the plaster is falling. You may arrange to have any repairs needed to these parts carried out.

Some of the desks should be revarnished and there are several which need to be fastened to the floor. The Inspector has found that some which are fastened are too far from the seats - that the desks do not overhang the lowered seat by from 1½ to 2 inches for best results. You may arrange to have the desks revarnished where needed and re-arrange all the desks in accordance with the Inspector's recommendation: they should all be properly fastened to the floor.

All the above work should be performed during the coming summer holidays and as cheaply as possible. You will forward properly certified vouchers in duplicate covering the expenditure incurred. You have already been authorized to arrange for the repairs needed to the roof and plaster. No doubt, you can arrange with Chief John W. Maracle to do the other work mentioned above.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mission School on the Tyendinaga Reserve, has drawn attention to the condition of the well. His report is as follows:

"That hole, dug for a well is in worse condition than ever. It is uncovered now and nearly full of water. If a child fell in he might easily drown.

If you think that you would get satisfactory water, why do you not have it properly stoned up and covered. If it is useless fill it up and remove the menace to these children.

I understand that it has twice been cleaned out and allowed to cave in as often."

Please report whether you would advise that this well be stoned and a cover placed thereon, or, if it is not required, whether you would recommend that it be filled in. If you consider that the well should be put in a good state of repair, you should state the cost of having the work done, that is, having the well stoned and a good substantial cover placed over it. Your early reply will oblige in order that if it is decided to have any work done it can be carried out during the coming summer holidays.

June 23rd, 1924.

SIR,

In reply to your letter of June 16th Re Well, at the Mission School, I beg to say that when Mrs Brant was the Teacher she had several Picnic and raised about $45. to dig a well. The first Man that took the job dug the well down 20 feet and quit the job and it caved in in the spring of 1923 and in fall of 1923 H. Barnhart took the job to finish it and gleaned it all out did not stone it up and it has caved in again this spring. His excuse for not finishing the well was that the people in the section would not draw the stones for him as they agreed to do when he took the job.

I went and saw Mrs Brant who is at the head of the digging the well and told her that if they did not finish it during the holidays that it would have to be filled in and she said that she would try and have it finished before the school commences in September. She has Twenty Dollars on hand yet, and I think it will take about $40. to finish it.

If the well was stoned up at the present depth it would furnish plenty water for the school, and it would be a good thing to have water in the school yard, and I believe that we will finish it now.

Your Obedient Servant,

Dept of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa, November 5, 1925.

Sir:

Mr. Clarke, Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mission School on the Trendinga Reserve, states he is informed by the teacher that the snow is never shovelled to the toilets during the winter unless she, herself, does the work. The inspector states there is ample room to place these toilets to the north of the coal shed, without endangering the water supply. He also thinks wood manure can be more easily accessible in winter as there is always a path to the coal bin. He states he hopes that this matter will be attended to at once.

Please give your views regarding the inspector's recommendation. If it is too late this season to make any change in the situation of the toilets, would it not be possible to arrange with the janitor to see that the snow is removed and a good path made to these toilets. If you agree with the inspector that they should be removed to the site suggested, please give an estimate of the cost.

The inspector states that the well curb, which has been graded up with gravel, is sinking and that, to be safe, the waste water should be led at least 16 feet away from the well, by means of a trough, which could readily be made to do this. He also states that the well curb should be graded up again to prevent waste water sinking into the well. Please arrange to have the necessary grading carried out at once. No unnecessary expense should be incurred. If a trough is required to carry away the waste water from the well, you may have one installed.

Please reply as soon as possible regarding the toilets and also concerning the action that you will take in the grading of the well.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Tyendinaga Agency.

The following repairs and equipment are needed and recommended for the Mission Day School.

A new chair for the teacher, the present one is worn out.
Two new front desks No.2
Two new rear seats No.2 Single.
The stove is cracked and in poor condition, it should be replaced by a Furnacette, the same as installed in the Eastern Mohawk Day school. This has proved very satisfactory.
The outside shutters are lacking in both quantity and quality of paint; it should be painted next summer.
The two closets are placed in a hollow part of the lot and are too far from the building; they should be moved to higher ground and closer to the school. The screens in front of both closets need repairing; this should be done as soon as possible.
The floor in the boys' clothes closet is badly broken; a new floor is needed.
The front entrance door looks very shabby and dilapidated; it should be replaced by a new one when the building is being painted. The Teacher's residence attached to this school is in excellent condition and very comfortable, but it should have a dividing partition in the cellar to provide a fruit and vegetable compartment and also to prevent the water cistern from freezing during the winter months.
If sufficient lumber to make the partition, 27 x 8 ft. is available, the teacher will erect it himself without cost, Agent Campbell might purchase the necessary lumber and have it delivered at the residence.

Memorandum.

Mission Indian Day School - Tyendinaga Reserve.

School in very good condition except for some repairs which have been authorized but which have not been done. Attendance is very good considering the weather.

Norman Clause, newly appointed truant officer, is reported as doing his work very satisfactorily and already a change in the attendance is noticeable.

I hope to make another visit to this reserve before the schools close for summer holidays and will make a full report upon conditions of school activities.

Inspector.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my visit of inspection to the Tyendinaga Agency on the 30th and 31st ultimo.

SCHOOLS

There are four Indian Day schools in the agency with a total roll of 157. On the day of my visit there were 137 pupils present. The register shows a very satisfactory average attendance. The pupils are reported as making excellent progress. Discipline in the different schools is good and the deportment of the pupils shows the results of the interest taken in them by their teachers. Besides the regular curriculum they are taught the rudiments of agriculture, sewing, knitting and mending. The classrooms are well equipped and on the whole clean and well ventilated. The outside closets are not cleaned out often enough. They should be cleaned once a month during the summer months and treated with lime to prevent odor. This applies to all four schools.

Dear Sir:

I made an inspection of Mission School at Tyendinaga Reserve on Sept 21st in regards to health of pupils and beg to report as follows:

1. Inside dimensions - 29 ft long by 18 ft wide, with 2 small cloak rooms at entrance.

2. 50 pupils on register with an average attendance of 42. This is an increase of more pupils this year.

3. To accommodate this increase in pupils at least 5 more seats are required.

In regards to size of school adding 8 more seats cannot be done without overcrowding (and I believe it is overcrowded at present) and certainly not conducive to health of children. The cloak rooms are far too small and unhealthy.

The four Indian day schools have been closed during the month of July for the summer holiday period. General repair work found necessary at these schools is being done by Indian labour. Dear Sir:

It is noted from your report for the month of April that you recommend that the Tyendinaga Mission School and residence be painted this year.

There is $250.00 provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the four day schools on the Tyendinaga Reserve. If the painting of the Mission School and residence can be done with the amount available and at the same time leave a small balance for emergency repairs that may be required at the other three schools between now and the end of next March the Department has no objection to the painting mentioned in your letter.

Please let me know what quantities of paint would be necessary, also if Indians can be employed to do the work. If so, you should give an estimate of the cost of the labour. If white painters will have to be employed you should so advise me.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. H. M. Jones,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.
Dear Sir:

I thank you for your letter of May 11 re: my recommendation for the painting of the Tyendinaga Mission School and Residence this year.

I believe that this can be done and still leave enough to take care of repairs and improvements on the four Indian Day Schools for the balance of the fiscal year.

I have had one quotation from an Indian painter to supply labor and material necessary to give the school and residence two coats for $95.00, or this party will supply labor necessary for $55.00. I estimate the material will cost as follows:

- Under coat: 6 gals. @ $3.50 = $21.00
- 100 lbs. white lead = $13.00
- 5 gals. of oil @ $1.25 = $6.25
- 3 qts. of green outside paint = $4.00

Total = $44.25

I believe that this work can be done for $100.00 and if you will authorize, I would like to have it done next month. The present scheme is a light brown body with a dark brown trim but I propose to have these buildings painted white with a green trim and in doing so the four schools will then all have been painted alike in colour.

Yours very truly,

H. M. Judge,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

On making an inspection of the Mission Indian Day School of this Agency I find that some urgent repairs are needed as follows,

Four pieces of lumber 4" by 7' to repair the floor in the boys outhouse, 1 pair of 6" T hinges for the door of this building which is off, 100 feet of plain inch lumber to repair the walls of the shed and also to replace some boards missing from this building, which needs a new shingle roof. 10 bunches of No. 3 XXX nails are needed to re-roof the shed and fuel storage building. Only 12" strap hinge is needed for the shed door. 6 lbs of three inch nails and 15 lbs of shingle nails are needed.

In the class-room 4 window blinds 8' long with 36" rollers, one pane glass 9" X 14" with putty and brads, 10 lengths of 7" stove pipe and one 7" elbow are needed.

In the yard adjoining the school there is a large oak tree that is badly decayed at the base and is a menace to the school proper and the outbuildings and should be cut down, otherwise a strong wind will blow it down and damage be done to the buildings.

The estimated cost of materials should not exceed $30.00 and can be procured locally and the cost of labour should not exceed $20.00. The work can be done without interfering with the class-room when school re-opens on October 1st next.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The exterior of the Mission Bay school is not in bad state of repair but considerable work is necessary to the interior of the whole building. This structure is quite old and the wall plaster is in bad shape, being loose and broken from the lath in many places. The floors are in such a condition and have been repaired so often that the classroom cannot be kept warm from winds coming up through. The doors have been resung so often that there is no place on either the door or the door frame that can be utilized to make further repairs.

The following repairs are recommended for this school and grounds,

Remove all wall plaster to the lath and replace with ten-test or some suitable wall board and panel same. Above the wainscoting these walls are 7' high by 28' long and the ends are 3' high by 20' wide. The cloak-rooms are 6' square by 6' high.

Repair all wall plaster where needed and paint the same with a light colour to increase lighting in the class-room. The walls should also be painted a light colour to increase lighting. The wainscoting to be painted with an additional coat of its light grey.

Procure and install new doors on both the outside and inside of the school, one 6' 7" X 33" X 1 1/2" and the other 7' 4" X 3' X 1 1/2" on the outside that should have six small lames for lighting.

Procure and install two new door frames of a wood suitably hard to meet the wear and tear of a school. Install a new floor over the present one of 2" hard wood flooring, size 19' by 28' which excludes the platform at the end of the class-room.

Repair and nail down school desks.

Renew 10 new lengths of heavy stove pipe, 7" X 24".

Point chimney to prevent leakage in north end of building.

Cut down and remove dead pine tree.

Procure 1 1/2" T & G lumber to refloor porch 5' X 7'.

Install 36 coat hangers in the two cloak rooms.

Erect a new fence across the front of the school and teachers residence, 7 strand 4' high. Renew 15 fence posts and brace posts. Procure and install two small wire gates 3' X 4', one for entrance to the school and the other for entrance to the teachers residence, where there are no gates at present.

Place 3 loads of gravel at the entrance to the school and the outhouses.

To do a regular job of this nature some leeway will be necessary to purchase small items not now listed. It is estimated that the materials will cost at least $200.00 and the labour $150.00 to complete this work. An advance for wages should be made and accounted for by credit voucher.

Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Deseronto, Ont. November 23, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

The furnace at the Mission School Teachers Residence, Tyendinaga Reserve, needs a new set of grates and a new T pipe with check damper complete. This set of grates is composed of three pieces and the furnace was made by the Pease Foundry Company, Toronto, Ont. the model of furnace being a "Brampton # 17-34".

Through dampness the pipe is badly holed from rust and creates a fire and gas hazard and it will be necessary to have an exact duplicate made to ensure a proper fit and I believe the old check damper can be used in the new pipe. The total cost of these repairs should not exceed $10.00.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

REPORT ON TIERENHAGA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1943

Schools:

The attendance at the reserve day schools has improved considerably during the month of November, no doubt on account of the very favourable weather. Cheques were issued to the teachers so that they may procure manual training and sewing materials at their best convenience. A meeting of the teachers was held and a program of exhibits to be shown at the 1944 Fall Fair was arranged, as the Fair Board has agreed to set aside $25.00 for prizes for children's exhibits which articles will be made at the four schools under the supervision of the teachers. The teacher of Mission School reports the repairs made at that school during the summer has greatly increased and lighting in the class-room and also has made the school much warmer.

This equipment was installed on September 24th, and according to the report of the teacher yesterday, has been in constant use by the children in their play-time and both before and after school, and will I believe improve school attendance. The other teachers state that they are sure their attendance would improve if they had similar equipment, and we therefore hope to be given permission to purchase similar equipment for the other two schools.

J.H. McVicker,
Acting Indian Agent.

Please find enclosed requisitions for school materials for Eastern, Central and Mission Schools, Tyendinaga Reserve for the 1947-48 term.

Included in these requisitions are a number of items which can be purchased locally, and I would recommend that authority be forwarded to this office for these articles.

I would advise that at Mission School there is seating capacity for 32 pupils only and the attendance at present is 36, necessitating the use of the teacher's desk by some of the younger children. A survey of the immediate vicinity reveals that the fall attendance will be approximately 41 pupils—which number cannot be accommodated at Mission School. To offset overcrowding it will be necessary to direct some of the children to Eastern and Central schools but these children will then have considerable further distance to travel, thus creating hardship on them. It is recommended that if any programme of school building is contemplated, that consideration be given to either a new Mission school or the building of a consolidated school for Tyendinaga Reserve, with a school bus service.

The teacher of Eastern School, Miss N. Stoddart, reports that she has not as yet received the yearly report form which should have been submitted to the department, and we request that these forms be forwarded to her at your earliest convenience.

J.H. McVicker,
Clerk-in-Charge.

- 1 step ladder,

I would acknowledge your letter of January 23rd, your file 34-3-8, in connection with the repairs to be made to the teacher's residence at the Mission School, Tyendinaga Reserve, and would advise that I have this morning received advance cheque 60459 for $40.00 to be used for wages in making these repairs.

I would further advise you that no major repair or decorating has been made to this residence for over 15 years and, to do a good job, the cost is going to exceed the estimated $100.00 as I advised you in my letter of January 10th. In my letter I asked for $60.00 for wages and only received an advance of $40.00 and I would ask that an additional $40.00 be sent forward as this amount will be needed to complete the work. It is also expected that the cost of materials will exceed the $40.00 authorized by $25.00 at least, which would bring the total repairs to the vicinity of $150.00.

No furniture was supplied for this residence for 15 years and what small amount on hand has been roughly handled and a part of it unfit for use. I have purchased a complete bedroom outfit for the use of Mrs. Elliot to a cost of $109.00 and she has her own furniture to equip the other rooms of the residence which she is prepared to use in view of the fact she is being supplied with a bedroom outfit. The suit consists of bed, a dresser, chest of drawers, a mattress, springs and a bench and is very moderately priced.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR CLARKE ON THE TYENDINAGA WESTERN SCHOOL.

At present the attendance is somewhat better but of the 26 registered the greatest number present on any day since vacation was 19. How can there be satisfactory progress.

I have no authority over your teachers, but it would be well if you would point out to all your teachers that we expect the standard raised to that of the white schools just as fast as possible, and if she used the language credited to her advise her not to do so again. I do not think she works as hard as some of the other teachers, but I see them so seldom that I would not like to be too positive in my opinion. I do know that the standard is lower than in white schools, and as I say in the reports I expect better work in the lower grades now that these girls are trained.

You know these Indians better than I do, but that man this morning seemed to be quite an intelligent man, and if what he says is true, it should be stopped.

Do you know why the Indians object so to these girls? There seems to be quite a feeling against them in some quarters. With the present supply of teachers, you

Teacher - Helen Lewis. One year at High School.

I recommended on last report that this girl be required to attend summer model school in order to learn something about the work she has undertaken to do. She did not go and you are getting very small returns for your money.

Ottawa, November 7th, 1922.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Clarke, in a report on his recent inspection of the Western school on the Tyendinaga Reserve, states that the services of the present teacher, Miss Helen Lewis, are most unsatisfactory, and that no progress is being made by the pupils in the classroom. He states it can hardly be expected that a young girl with only one year at high school can have the necessary experience. He further states that it is a waste of money, from the results achieved, to continue Miss Lewis' services.

In view of the Inspector's report, I would request that you endeavour to obtain the services of another teacher to take charge of this school at the beginning of the new year. In the meantime, Miss Lewis may remain as teacher. You will be good enough to keep this matter in mind and, if possible, obtain the services of a teacher with the necessary qualifications. We would be prepared to pay a larger salary to a qualified teacher - the amount allowed to depend upon the qualifications possessed.

I will be pleased to have a report from you stating whether you consider it would be possible to obtain the services of another teacher to begin duties after the new year.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, August 8, 1905.

Memorandum:

Chief Sampson Green and Councillor Andrew Maracle called at the Department today and stated that the Indians of the Tyendinaga Band in Council had decided on putting the four school-houses on the reserve as well as the Council-house in a proper state of repair and they estimate that it would cost about $1000.00 to do this.

As two of the schools (namely, the Mission School and the "brick" School,) open soon, the Council have had the repairs done to these schools and they purpose going ahead and doing the others in the same way, as well as the Council-house,- the accounts for which will be duly passed upon by the Council and forwarded to the Department through the Agent for payment.

It will be necessary as soon as the resolution of the Council is before the Department to obtain an Order in Council authorizing the expenditure from capital for this work.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, 9th August, 1906.

Sir,

Referring to the resolution of the Indian Council of Tyendinaga, dated the 1st instant relating to the repairs of school-houses, and council-house on the reserve, I beg to inform you that an Order in Council will be immediately applied for authorising the expenditure from the capital funds of the band of the sum estimated as the cost of the work, namely $1,000.

I have, however, to request you to specify in detail the repairs required to each building and the estimated cost thereof, and to send the same for the information of the Department. It is presumed that the work will be done by days' labour, under your general supervision.

Referring to your letter of 23rd Nov 1905.

It behooves me to say as to the purchase of a clock, whether it would be impossible to buy a clock such as is required for this school for the amount you mention viz £2 as the clock required would be one to hang on the wall so that all the scholars could be able to see the time which could not be bought for less than £5 or £4.

The blinds I shall at once procure and shall see that they are properly put on the windows.

As to the well I could not recommend an expense of this kind as the well would be deep and I should think would cost with pump about £5, and there would be no small amount of water used probably two quarts per day. The water therefore would have a tendency to be foul and bad therefore imperilling the health of the children. I may say there is a well about 200 yards from the school at a farm house the water of which is excellent owing to a lot of water being used. This school has been using this well for years and being nearest to the school it would appear an unnecessary expense to dig a well as we would not have nearly as good water.

Sir,

I have again to call your attention to your neglect of your duty in regard to school matters on the Tyendinaga Reserve.

Since your appointment as Indian Agent for this reserve you have failed to send in the monthly reports called for on the four schools under your charge and it is presumed that you have made no official visits to these schools during that time. You have also disregarded the Department's instructions to furnish an annual report on the work of these schools, although the fiscal year closed on March 31st, last.

As a result of your negligence the teachers of these schools are kept out of their quarterly salaries, no returns having been received from you for the quarter ending March 31st, last. Sir,

Western School

This building is very poor and I strongly recommend the erection of a new school building at an early date as possible. I have never seen as poor a building as this one made use of as a school. The building was moved some years ago and was badly wrecked and it is impossible to repair it satisfactorily. The school was not in session. The teacher stated she had dismissed the children on account of the cold. No wood being in the school. This was a flimsy excuse as in none of the schools was there any fire on the day I visited them. I visited them all the same day. A new teacher should be secured as soon as possible.

There appears to be 22 on the roll; 5 boys and 6 girls had been at the school the morning of the day I visited the school.

The building is in poor condition and before another winter a new building should be erected.

Ottawa, August 8th, 1918.

Memorandum Mr. Scott,

On my recent visit to Tyendinaga reserve to procure data in reference to condition of schools, I inspected the Western school and beg to report that this school is similar in size and design to the Mission school, but is in worse condition as the walls at foundation are bulging outwards until the sills are almost plumb with eaves of roof, although walls have been tied in with rods to prevent further spreading and the collapse of the building.

A new shingled roof is also required as the shingles are badly broken and rotting off. The lean-to entrance addition also requires a new felt roof, the present one being entirely worn out and leaking badly, and should be replaced as soon as possible.

The school building is lighted on the two sides with two windows in each. The class-rooms being 20 x 30 with floor space for 34 pupils and air space for 24, the number enrolled.

The average attendance is 12, being one-half of the number registered, which is scarcely a creditable showing.
The school grounds are 117 x 197 ft. with gradual fall to rear of lot, admitting of satisfactory drainage for basement under school.

As a new building is necessary and should be erected next year, I would recommend that sufficient patching only be done to render the roof temporarily water proof until a new building is ready.

Architect.

More drinking cups are necessary.

Outbuildings are badly in need of cleaning and as in the case of the Central School, are much too far from the school and too near to one another.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Western school on the Tyendinaga Reserve, draws attention to the condition of the closets. He states that they are badly in need of cleaning; that they are much too far away from the school and too near to each other.

I have to request that you will arrange to have these closets thoroughly cleaned out and placed in a good sanitary condition before the school reopens after the summer holidays. No unnecessary expense should be incurred, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost.

The Inspector has also drawn attention to the necessity of individual drinking cups at this and other schools on the Reserve. You might interview the teachers as to the arrangements that could be made if individual cups are provided. It would be useless to supply these cups if each child did not at all times use the one provided for his sole use. You might state, if individual cups are provided, if the teachers could arrange to see that each child uses only his own cup. I should be pleased to have a report as to whether you would advise that these individual cups be supplied at each of the schools.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

G. H. Campbell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Deseronto, Ont.

There are four Indian Day schools in the agency with a total roll of 157. On the day of my visit there were 139 pupils present. The register shows a very satisfactory average attendance. The pupils are reported as making excellent progress. Discipline in the different schools is good and the deportment of the pupils shows the results of the interest taken in them by their teachers. Besides the regular curriculum they are taught the rudiments of agriculture, sewing, knitting and mending. The classrooms are well equipped and on the whole clean and well ventilated. The outside closets are not cleaned out often enough. They should be cleaned once a month during the summer months and treated with lime to prevent odor. This applies to all four schools.

Thos. Mc Cookin,
Inspector.

Dear Sir:

Please be advised that a few small repairs are necessary at the Western Indian Day School on Tyendinaga Reserve and that the following materials are needed,

Latch for one outhouse door.
60 lineal feet of 4" corner board.
60 lineal feet 5" corner board.
1 pane glass 7" X 9" with putty and brads.
1 piece of 2 X 4", 12 feet long.
2 lbs 2½ inch nails.

The screen and boxes at the outhouses at this school need repairing, the posts of the screen having been heaved out of the ground by frost and should be again set up properly. A water pail and a small fire shovel are needed in the class-room.

The pump at this school has been out of action for nearly a year due to the cylinder and plunger arm becoming unscrewed from the pump proper and dropping to the bottom of the well, where it no doubt now is embeded in silt. It will need the services of a plumber or well driller to secure this part from this drilled hole and this repair should be made, as the school is now using water from a nearby creek which is dirty and unfit for use.

There are three holes in the bottom section of the fire-box of the coal furnacette in use at this school and this is a danger as live coals drop out and it is becoming more of a danger from fire all the time. This stove is built by the J. S. Stewart Mfg. Co., Woodstock, Ont. being a Hard Service Series, Good Cheer No. 520 model. A new part should be procured and installed as I believe these parts can be gotten separate and will take an experienced man to make the change of parts. Failing to be able to get parts it is possible the present part might be taken to a foundry and repaired.
The cost of the small repairs to the building should not exceed $12.00 for materials and labour. I am not able to give an estimate for the repairing of the pump or the stove as the cost of the pump will mainly be based on the time taken to get the lost part out of the well as a new cylinder could not be installed until the other is secured. The cost for the stove will depend on being able to procure the separate part.

Your obedient servant,

Deseronto, Ont., December 10, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of November 3rd, File 34-4-5 concerning the repairs to be made to the pump at the Western Indian Day School, I would advise that this well was drilled by Mr. Gartley of Belleville whom I engaged to make the necessary repairs.

Mr. Gartley now advises me that there is nothing can be done to clear out the present drilled hole of this well and recommends that a new hole be drilled with an estimated cost of $70.00. When this pump was broken nearly two years ago part of the pump dropped to the bottom of the drilled hole and through negligence the hole was never plugged with the results that children or other persons have thrown rocks and debris down the hole to within twelve feet of the surface, all of which could have been eliminated if a wooden plug had been driven in the top of the well casing. Mr. Gartley does not consider any well driller can clear out the old hole at any less expense than drilling a new one.

As the school is at the present time using water obtained from Mud Creek adjacent to the school which is far from ideal for use, it is recommended that a new well be drilled at as early a date as possible if funds are available from the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

While the Western Day school is in a fairly good state of maintenance, some small minor repairs are needed and should be made during the holiday period.

Replace two panes of glass in storm windows, the glass being procured by the pupil who broke same. Procure an ash pan for coal heater 14" X 16" by 5" high.

Repair or replace two locks with door knobs as well for inside ante-rooms.

Replace two boards on outhouse screen and re-set posts holding the screen.

Procure one-half cord of light slab wood for fire lighting purposes.

Build a small tool shed for the storing of garden tools, storm windows, etc., on south side of the coal shed. Size 4' X 8' by 7' high of T & G. lumber.

Procure and install a storm window 2' X 3' with four panes to cover air vent in the gable on the north side of the school.

At the present time there is no where except the coal bin to store any extra supplies, tools or windows and these are continually being broken by having wood or coal piled on them and a little shed would not cost much to build for storage purposes and could be placed out of sight behind the coal shed and kept closed with a pad-lock.

Through rain and snow coming in the air vent in the gable end, the ceiling and walls are being damaged and a window with glass should be put on hinges to be opened in warm weather and closed during the colder season. A wire screen could also be nailed on the inside to prevent birds, bees, etc., making a nesting place in the loft of this school.

The cost of materials for repairs at this school should not exceed $25.00 and the cost of labour $20.00 and it is requested that an advance for payment of wages be sent forward to this office, to be accounted for by credit voucher.

Dear Sir:

At the present time there are a total of twenty-four Indian children attending the Shannonville and Milltown public schools on whose account the department is paying tuition fees until the end of the present school term. Unless the Indian parents pay these fees themselves to continue to send their children to these white schools, they will of necessity have to attend Western Indian Day School and the desk accommodation at this school is far from satisfactory. If all Indian children attend there would be an enrollment of thirty-eight.

The present desks are the old double obsolete type and should be replaced with new single desks in various sizes to properly accommodate the pupils. The present desks are mainly small and cramp the children and are unsanitary when a school is crowded for seating accommodation.

Please find enclosed voucher 296, amounting to $118.60, in favor of Mr. George Chalk, Box 435, Napanee, Ont. and being payment for drilling a well, repairing and installing a pump at Western Indian Day School.

In the late fall of 1941, I had made arrangements with Mr. Gartley, Belleville, Ont. to drill this well and his estimate for drilling and expected depth of 32 ft., was approximately $70.00. This man lost his equipment through a fire and could not do this work and it made necessary the engagement of Mr. Chalk as there is no other well driller in this part of the country.

To properly protect the well and to save filtration of sand, which caused the trouble in the old well, it was necessary to drill and case a hole, forty ft. in depth. The cost of repairs and parts, to the old pump, were quite expensive although a good well has been secured and strict instructions have been given to the teacher and pupils, with regard to future care of this pump, so that there should not be a repetition of the neglect in not capping the well hole, which caused a new well to be drilled.

A. D. Moore, Indian Agent.

REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

EDUCATION.

Due to severe weather in the early part of the month and to thawing in the latter part, the roads of the reserve were blocked most of the month from either snow or water and the attendance of children from outlying parts of the reserve was poor. The local Indian Constable did make a trip concerning truants to two of the Agency schools. A new well for drinking water was drilled at the Western School, which had been urgently needed for some time. Due to unsatisfactory attention to his duties, Isaac Maracle was relieved of his caretaking at Mission School and Morris Maracle assumed these duties. Mrs. Gladys Maracle continues as teacher at the Mission School, although I am continuing to make inquiries for a suitable teacher as replacement at some future date.

A.D. Moore,
Indian Agent.
