Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Tyendinaga Western Indian Day School.

As a result of my recent inspection trip to the Tyendinaga Reserve, we have made the following decisions:

1. To postpone the building of a new school near the site of the present Tyendinaga Eastern building.

2. To re-open the Tyendinaga Western School, which has been closed for about three years. This building is in good condition and with the painting of the inside and outside will again be a creditable little day school. A new roof will also be needed but it will be much cheaper than erecting a new building some 8 miles away.

3. To transport the surplus children from the Tyendinaga Eastern School to the newly re-opened Western School. We have selected a group of children who are now walking between 2½ and 4 miles to the Eastern School and will transport them to the Western School. During most of the year it will be possible, by using a back road, to get them to this school over a route of about 7 miles. During heavy snows the route will be much longer and may approximate 12 miles.

4. That a tender be obtained from local taxi drivers in Deseronto for the transportation of these children. Please find attached a tender which Mr. Indian Superintendent Cassie has forwarded. In his covering letter he states as follows:
"Enclosed please find a tender to transport the children to Western School. This driver is quite reliable and do us a good job. He will use a 7 passenger Dodge car (3 seats). His price is figured for 10 - 14 children and does not seem unreasonable to me. Also if the teacher should reside in Deseronto, she would be able to ride with him by paying her way and this would cut our costs by that amount."

While I did not meet Mr. Marsale during my visit, I am informed that he is a reliable Indian who has been in the taxi business for some years in Deseronto and whose taxis are used by white and Indians alike.

I would like to discuss this contract with you when opportunity presents itself.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Deseronto, Ont.

AGREEMENT FOR TRANSPORTATION

MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this Eighteenth day of July, One Thousand Nine Hundred and Forty-Nine:

BETWEEN: Russell Maracle, Deseronto, Ont. in the County of Hastings, Province of Ontario, hereinafter called the Operator of THE FIRST PART,

AND: INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH, Department of Mines and Resources, Deseronto, Ont., hereinafter called the Party of the Second Part,

WITNESSETH THAT in consideration of the mutual covenants, agreements and undertakings herein contained the Operator on behalf of himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, and the Party of the Second Part and their successors mutually covenant and agree as follows:

1. The Operator shall transport to and from Western Bay School each School day all pupils, designated by the Party of the Second Part, from the Tyendinaga Reserve who are in attendance at the school during the period covered by this contract, the estimated number being 12 pupils and one teacher.

2. This contract shall commence 1st day of September 1949 and terminate 30th day of June 1950.

3. The Operator shall use a motor vehicle properly licensed and insured as required by The Public Vehicle Act and the Regulations thereunder.

4. The Operator shall follow a route described as follows, leaving Deseronto and proceeding west to the Ferry Lane, thence north to the York Road and West to the Western School.

5. The first pupil shall be picked up not later than 8:30 a.m. Roads and weather permitting, the vehicle shall arrive at the school at 8:45 a.m. It shall leave the school at 4:15 p.m. and shall follow the route in the opposite direction.

6. The cost of all insurance shall be paid by the Operator.

7. The Party of the Second Part shall pay to the Operator the sum of $5.00 per day for each day transportation service is provided.

8. The Operator shall pick up the pupils at any place on the route where the pupils may be, and shall permit them to alight at any place which they designate unless the stops on the route are designated by the Party of the Second Part.

9. In case of any accident causing personal injuries to any pupil, the Operator shall not be relieved from liability by reason of the vehicle being operated off the route described in Paragraph 4 of this Agreement, whether or not the vehicle is operated off the route with or without the consent of the Operator, and whether or not the vehicle is operated off the route at the request or consent of any passenger.

10. It is agreed between the Party of the Second Part that while the vehicle is operated on any private road or other place he shall assume the same liability as is imposed upon him by The Highway Traffic Act while the vehicle is operated on a highway.

11. The Operator shall be deemed to be in the business of carrying passengers for compensation, notwithstanding payment or lack of payment under the terms of this Agreement and notwithstanding any lack of power on the part of the Party of the Second Part to enter into this Agreement.

12. This Agreement may be terminated by mutual consent of the Party of the Second Part and the Operator or, on the last day of any calendar month, provided that written notice to that effect is given by either of the parties to the other at least one month prior to the said date.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the Party of the First Part has set his hand and seal and the parties of the Second Part have hereunto set their hands and seals.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 11th ultimo with reference to the prosecution of parents for failure to have their children attend school as provided by the Act, and note your enquiry as to whether the children of Johnson, a white man residing on the reserve, can be compelled to attend school.

In reply, I beg to say that the provisions of the Act relating to compulsory attendance of children at school applies only to Indian children. Mr. Johnson, being a white man has no legal right to reside on the Reserve, and if he is unwilling to have his children attend school as Indian children, his removal from the Reserve altogether might be considered. It is thought that when you advise him as to his situation, he may be willing to send his children to school without further trouble.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of recent date in which you recommend that the Mountain Road Indian Day School be closed at the end of the present school year, viz: June 30th, next, and that a school be opened in the teacher's residence at Mission Bay.

In reply I beg to say that it is considered the teacher's residence at Mission Bay would not be suitable for school purposes. If it were used as a classroom there would be no accommodation for a teacher. Besides, it is considered that it would be necessary to still conduct the school at Mountain Road to provide educational facilities for the children residing on that part of the Reserve. The Department recognizes the need of a school at Mission Bay, as Mr. Bennett, the Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Mountain Village school stated that there were 20 children at Mission Bay for whom school facilities should be provided.

At the present time we have no funds available for the erection of a new school building at Mission Bay and until such is available, the question of erecting a building and providing educational facilities at this point will have to remain in abeyance.

Dear Sir,

The situation as to children of school age living at the Mountain Road Village on the Indian Reserve has come before me several times recently and I have become seized of the unfortunate position in which these children are situate.

There are at least ten children that should have some chance of attending school. Of this ten there are only three, according to the information which I have, who are definitely wards of your Department. The others are the children of Indian women married to white men or adopted Indian children from other Bands or other localities.

There is a school house with all the equipment lying idle and vacant. The only thing that seems to be required is a school teacher and I am told that one of the young Indian woman, the wife of one of the young Indians, is a school teacher who formerly taught school at Squaw Bay, and that arrangements could be made whereby she would conduct the school at a comparatively small salary.

It so happens that by reason of my position as Chairman of the Board of Park Management, and because in that capacity I have been actively engaged in the work of development of Chippewa Park, I have necessarily
THE DEPT.SUPT.-GEN.

10-14-22.

In consequence become acquainted with the general situation in both of the Indian villages as we have been endeavouring to use wherever possible, Indian labor from both villages.

It is from the knowledge thus acquired and a certain amount of sympathy with the position in which these children are, that this letter is being written and I am writing in the first place to your Department in the hope that you will be able to furnish me information as to how far your Department would go towards paying the salary of this teacher. If you cannot give me that information my intention is to take it up with the Provincial Department of Education and see what they can do towards the salary of a teacher to the end that there might be worked out some plan by means of which the children in this village could have schooling.

I will be very glad if you will let me have any information you can in connection with the matters discussed in this letter.

Yours truly,

Sir -

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the providing of educational facilities for the children of school age residing at Mountain Head Village.

As you may be aware, we conducted a school for a number of years on this Reserve, but in May, last, our Agent, Mr. W. R. Brown, Port Arthur, recommended that it be closed as there were only three Indian children attending. The school was, therefore, closed at the end of the last school year, viz: June 30th. We re-opened the school at Mission Bay on the 1st of September, last, and instructed our Agent to forward all school material, etc., from the Mountain Village school to Mission Bay, which we understand has been done.

In view of the recommendation received for the closing of the Mountain Village school on the ground that there were only three Indian children attending, I do not consider that we would be warranted in undertaking the expense of having the school re-opened or providing a grant towards the salary of a teacher.

Yours truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your favor of the 16th inst., and have carefully noted contents.

The fact, does, however, stand out that there are three Indian children who cannot possibly receive any Education of any kind unless there is some schooling provided at the Mountain Road Village. The total number of children who are in this position, according to the information I have, are ten or eleven.

If for the purpose of providing schooling for these ten or eleven children an arrangement could be made by means of which the teacher could be provided at say $300.00, and I could succeed in getting an appropriation from the Province of $100.00, from the City of $100.00 and from the Department of $100.00, this would cover the item.

Under these circumstances would it not be worth while still considering the possibility of making such a Grant? I would be very glad to hear further from you.

OTTAWA, November 7th, 1922.

Madam:

Replying to your telegram of the 6th instant, I beg to say that this Department is not re-opening the Mountain Village School. We have been advised, however, that some interested parties are anxious to secure school facilities for the few Indian and half-breed children residing at that point, and that they are trying to arrange with the Provincial Department of Education and the School Board of the City of Fort William to provide the necessary funds to pay the salary of a teacher and other expenses. This Department has agreed to provide the sum of $100 as its share of salary and expenses.

We are informed that the total salary that would be paid a teacher for the few children who would attend would be approximately $300 per annum. If the school is re-opened, it will be under the control of the Provincial Department of Education, and this Department will be responsible for the payment of the amount mentioned above only. You will, therefore, see that nothing would be gained by a transfer, and we hope that you will remain as teacher at the Mission Bay School.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Prudhomme:

Replying to your letter of the 20th ultimo, I beg to say that I have looked over the returns received from you since you began duties at the Mountain Village School. I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th inst., and in reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased to learn that the matters referred to in its letter of the 9th inst., are receiving attention.

Your suggestion that the Inspector should make recommendations to you or leave orders with you cannot be entertained. All recommendations must be made to the Department and no work should be undertaken without authority. The Department would have much preferred modern desks for this school, and the same applies to the blackboard, so that the equipment might harmonise with the new building.

In all these matters you will be good enough in future to consult the Department before taking any action.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

H. McDougall, Esq.,

Sir,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant in reference to repairs needed to the school-house and residence at Mountain Village. In reply I beg to say that you are hereby authorized to have this work done by Ambrose Gyrette. You may supply him with the necessary material and you will be good enough to see that the work is expeditiously done. In a letter of the 13th instant you were asked to give the sizes of the black board and the desks. You have omitted to furnish this information. The Department does not consider it advisable to make black boards as they never give proper satisfaction. If you will give the exact size of the board, one of hyloplate will be ordered. In regard to the desks, if you will send in a diagram of the school room showing the position they should be placed in, the Department can then order them and it will not be necessary for you to give the sizes.

If Gyrette is a reliable man, it is thought that the better way is to pay him by the day at a fair rate. All work to be done under your supervision and completed to your satisfaction.

Sir,

I am in receipt of yours of 11th inst.

No. 542,322-5 with cheque for $10.83 enclosed. The item of $6.00 which is for account of Xavier McLaren for putting together and setting up school desks and which you think is an excessive charge and ask for an explanation.

With regard to this, I may state that the desks arrived knocked down and had to be put together before being put in place. This took McLaren two days. An expert mechanic might have done the work in one day or a little longer but, it was not possible to get a mechanic to go to the Reserve for so small a job. McLaren was the only member of the band whom I could depend on to do the work satisfactorily. His kit of tools was not such as to enable him to do the work quickly.

I allowed him $5.00 per day which is $1.00 per day less than carpenters receive at Fort William.

Your faithfully,

Acting Agent

Report of Inspector J.F. Finn on Mt. McKay School.

School House--
Very dirty. It hasn't been cleaned since November last.

Blackboards--
This is one of the most important things in the equipment of any school and at present is very poor in quality and quantity. An additional blackboard is required.

School Grounds--
Low and wet. These grounds could be easily improved with a few loads of sand.
Ottawa, May 22, 1914.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Finn, in his report on the Mountain School, states that the school-house is very dirty, that an additional blackboard is required and that the grounds are low and wet and could easily be improved with a few loads of sand.

You will be good enough to see that the school-house is cleaned at once and that it is kept clean in future. It should be swept daily and scrubbed at intervals.

You will be good enough to state the dimensions of the blackboard required and hyloplate will be ordered from the Stationery Office.

The Department would like to have an estimate of the probable cost of making the necessary improvements to the school grounds.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. Russell Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.
